Subject: RE: [sfraves]nrr: DJs! 33 and 45 rpms?

A quick search and this is what I found-

http://members.tripod.com/~Vinylville/spindoc.html 



Explainations of why certain speeds were chosen for certain types of
phonograph recordings... 

s p i n s   d o c t o r e d
___________________________ 

    q. Does anyone know why 78 revolutions per minute was chosen
    as the standard rotation speed of old-fashioned gramophone
    records, rather than a round number such as 75 or 80 rpm?
    And are there convincing explanations for the choice of
    speeds for later EPs and LPs of 33 1/3 rpm and 45 rpm?

    JAMES LEE
    Oisterwijk
    The Netherlands
    ____________________________________________________________

    a. It was Emil Berliner, the inventor of the gramophone, who
    determined roughly how fast old disc records should spin. He
    avoided Edison's need for a stylus made from precious jewels
    by using points which could be made from steel sewing
    needles and pins. The size of the stylus effectively
    determined the size of the grooves in a record and the
    recordable frequency range limited by this groove size
    determined a speed between 70 and 90 rpm.

    Standardisation did not begin until 1912, when the British
    Gramophone Company conducted listening tests on their back
    catalogue. They settled on the average (or possibly the
    median) of these tests, which turned out to be 78 rpm. Other
    companies adopted this, but the process was not complete
    until the early 1930s. Even after this date rogue rpm
    records still appeared. After standardisation problems still
    occurred. Because of electrical mains frequencies
    differences on opposite sides of the Atlantic, stroboscopic
    speed testers and synchronous motors meant a nominal speed
    of 77.922 rpm in countries that used 50 hertz and 78.261 in
    countries that used 60 hertz. These were later fixed in
    national (but not international) standards. 

    Records of 33 1/3 rpm were developed in conjunction with
    films. A 12-inch 78 with Berliner-type grooves could hold
    between 4 and 5 minutes per side. The first practical sound
    films produced in the US in the late 1920s had their sound
    on separate disc records and it was more important for the
    sound to be continuous. A reel of film might run for 11
    minutes, so a rotational speed of about 32 rpm was required
    to make the sound match the picture. History doesn't tell us
    why precisely 33 1/3 was chosen, but in retrospect it was a
    very good choice because stroboscopic speed testers can be
    made for this speed which will work on both sides of the
    Atlantic. 

    It seems CBS engineers (who developed the first LPs in
    1948), simply experimented with one of the old machines
    hanging around in their workshop. They then developed new
    groove dimensions which gave an acceptable signal-to-noise
    ratio with the new plastic material "vinyl". 

    The 45 rpm speed was the only one to be decided by a precise
    optimisation procedure (by RCA Victor in 1948). Calculus was
    used to show that the optimum use of a disc record of
    constant rotational speed occurs when the innermost recorded
    diameter is half the outermost recorded diameter. That's why
    a 7-inch single has a label 3 1/2 inches in diameter. Given
    the CBS vinyl groove dimensions and certain assumptions
    about the bandwidth and tolerable distortion, a speed of 45
    rpm comes out of the formula. 

    PETER COPELAND
    British Library National Sound Archive 
    London 


    a. From 1894 to around 1930, there were many different
    record speeds ranging from 65 to 90 rpm, each case being a
    compromise between playing time and the need for a clean cut
    in the original wax. The Victor company used 76 rpm for many
    years for its recordings but instructed buyers to reproduce
    at 78 rpm, the record's durability was improved that way.
    The standard of 78 rpm arrived by default, although the
    actual speed depended on the electrical mains frequency.
    Constant linear speed, or varying the rpm, was
    commercialised but did not prove to be a success (until the
    arrival of the CD). 

    The speed of 33 1/3 was introduced in 1927 after theoretical
    analysis of the compromise between signal-to-noise ratio and
    playing time (3 minutes per radial inch) by J. P. Maxfield
    of Bell Laboratories for sound films produced on the
    Vitaphone system. And it was a professional de facto
    standard before it became commercialised by CBS in 1948. It
    has been suggested that 78 minus 33 equals 45 was the reason
    for the emergence of 45 rpm records but, in fact, Maxfield's
    analysis still applies: the 45 "single" was RCA's equivalent
    to a 10-inch, 78 rpm record, only smaller. 

    GEORGE BROCK-NANNESTAD
    Copenhagen 
    Denmark 


    a. Emil Berliner's first disc gramophones were wound by hand
    at somewhere between 60 and 100 rpm. The 7-inch discs lasted
    a minute or so and had low sound quality. Berliner and his
    assistant Fred Gaisberg realised that unless the speed was
    governed, the gramophone would never be more than a novelty.
    Gaisberg visited a young mechanic who was making clockwork
    machinery, hoping to use it for sewing machines. This
    machinery was never successful in sewing machines, but was
    ideal for gramophones, and it rotated at 78 rpm. The
    mechanic, Eldridge Johnson, became a millionaire. Columbia
    made all its discs to run at 80 and HMV had its pioneer
    recordings produced between 68 and 92 rpm with the key of
    the piece marked on the label. You then tuned it on your own
    piano, using the gramophone's governor. These speeds all
    gradually settled into the standard of 78. 

    When talking pictures first arrived in the late 1920s, the
    sound was recorded separated on discs and had to be
    synchronised by the projectionist at each showing. Every
    cinema projection room had a pair of projectors, each taking
    1000-feet reels of film, whose running time was about 10
    minutes. The projectionist switched projectors after each
    reel. Ideally, this meant that the sound should last 10
    minutes as well, as it would be impossible to synchronise a
    sound changeover in midreel. At the time, however, a 12 inch
    78 rpm record lasted for only about 4 minutes, so the
    Vitagraph company simply slowed down the 78 until it lasted
    10 minutes and recorded all their masters on that, starting
    each disc in the middle, as it was easier to drop a needle
    there than the outer edge. This new speed was 33 1/3 rpm,
    adopted for other records in the late 1940s when Columbia
    introduced its first vinyl, long-play discs with
    microgrooves, giving a play time of about 30 minutes on each
    side. 

    However, the long-play disc wasn't particularly suitable to
    popular music, as the public wanted its records as singles
    with good sound quality even at high volumes. RCA Victor
    came up with a 7-inch vinyl disc with microgrooves, rotating
    at 45 rpm, a speed chosen specifically to make the most of
    the music, unlike 78s or 33 1/3s. And does no one remember
    the 16s? 

    ROGER WORSLEY
    Haverfordwest 
    Pembrokeshire 


Jason Andrews
Sample Department
Columbia Sportswear

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 21 Nov 2003 00:42:09.0283 (UTC) FILETIME=[4B943530:01C3AFC8]

Subject: [sfraves] Re: On being a slut


>
>	Let's examine what it would mean to truly fuck people at random. This 
>would mean, walking down the street, that the person would be as likely to 
>come onto an 80-year-old guy as a 20-year-old guy. And that's just for 
>starters. Next you'd have to imagine no preferences for looks, disability 
>status, gender, or personal hygiene.

I dunno...I have seen some people be truly un-selective about whom they 
fuck. About the only selection there was boiled down to "the other person is 
willing to hump me, so I'm going for it". If that's not ebing fairly random, 
I dunno what is.


>
>	Have you ever met anyone of whom you think this is true? I haven't. So I 
>think we can safely forget about the idea that anyone is truly random in 
>his or her choice of sexual partners.

"Truly" random....this is an issue of semantics.


>
>	The feeling that looks shouldn't count for everything, and that 
>friendship, or at least the potential for it, should be in there somewhere, 
>is a common perspective. And I can sympathize with this desire for all sex 
>to be positive on all levels. In an ideal world, it would be.
>
>	I'd similarly prefer all my consumer interactions to be positive on all 
>levels. When I go shopping, I'd much rather give my money to someone with 
>whom I could have a conversation, or be friends, than somebody I don't find 
>very likable. But unfortunately I can't have solely positive consumer 
>interactions without greatly diminishing my quality of life. If I find a 
>really cool pair of shoes at a really great price, I'm not going to pass 
>them up just because I can't imagine myself being friends with the person 
>behind the counter. If I only bought goods or services from people I really 
>like, a lot of my needs would go unmet. I have yet to find a bank I feel 
>very good about, but I'm not willing to give up having a checking account.
>

Once you start comparing sex to consumer transactions, you ought to 
reevaluate your quality of life. But then again, since you admittidedly sell 
your own ass, you probably wouldn't understand what I was talking about 
anyway. Don't get me wrong...not knocking what you do. It takes all sorts of 
people to make the world go around. I'm just saying it takes a completely 
different mindset to operate on that level. I'm sure you'd agree....

>	I feel the same way about sex. Sure I'd prefer that all my partners be 
>nice people with whom I have something in common besides physical 
>attraction. But if Pam Anderson came to my door begging to be fucked do you 
>think I'd turn her away? Not a chance! Lots of people believe a willingness 
>to sleep with someone just on the basis of physical desire cheapens sex. I 
>disagree. You can still have sex with someone who resonates with you on 
>many levels and you care a lot about some other time, and perhaps even 
>enjoy it more than you would have without the other experience. A 
>nutritious salad tends to taste even better if all you've eaten all day are 
>chocolate eclairs. I'm not on a sexual diet, so why shouldn't I try to 
>enjoy both?

Now, the fact that you'd fuck Pamela Anderson (who not only is FOUL, but has 
been diagnosed with an agressive strain of Hepatitis C) TRULY scares me. 
This is what I mean by being selective, and not fucking people at random. 
Unless of course you don't mind sleeping with dirty, diseased skanks....lol.

M-

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."

-Spanish Proverb

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Precedence: bulk

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 21 Nov 2003 01:45:19.0992 (UTC) FILETIME=[1F047F80:01C3AFD1]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene

I have recently been dabbling in the concept of religion, and speaking to 
people close to me.  I know this cool kat, he was really involved in the 
scene in the early 90's.  He spoke of the full moon parties and love affair 
parties and so on.  He is trying to find a medium between the rave scene and 
christianity.  While I think this is awesome, I think it would be a hard 
thing to accomplish, because I love swiggin on my hennessy and smokin on me 
smoke when Im gettn down.  He said I would be surprised how many christians 
do indulge in chronic or alcohol in moderation.  He had me listen to some 
hiphop and downtempo that was made by christians...  I was like, DAMN!  
These christian cats got flows!!  They weren't even flowing about jesus, the 
bible, or anything, they were flowin about what underground hiphop heads be 
flowin about.

I had this impression of what christian musician's would be like, and I was 
totally wrong!  Although, I am just at the tip of the iceberg, I would like 
to hear from you people about your understanding of christianity, music and 
the rave scene.  Or not even christianity, just spirituality in general.

peace

fable....

My friend Graham St. John, who has edited several works on rave culture, 
has just published a book that addresses this very topic.  He is also doing 
a followup work on the same subject and I'm slated to contribute an 
essay.  Info:

Rave Culture and Religion
(London, New York: Routledge 2004)

Vast numbers of western youth have attached primary significance to raving 
and post-rave experiences. This collection of essays explores the 
socio-cultural and religious dimensions of the rave, 'raving' and 
rave-derived phenomena.

Rave Culture and Religion provides insights on developments in 
post-traditional religiosity (especially 'New Age' and 'Neo-Paganism') 
through studies of rave's Gnostic narratives of ascensionism and 
re-enchantment, explorations of the embodied spirituality and millennialist 
predispositions of dance culture, and investigations of transnational 
digital-art countercultures manifesting at geographic locations as diverse 
as Goa, India, and Nevada's Burning Man festival. Contributors examine 
raving as a new religious or revitalization movement; a powerful locus of 
sacrifice and transgression; a lived bodily experience; a practice 
comparable with world entheogenic rituals; and as evidencing a new 
Orientalism. Rave Culture and Religion will be essential reading for 
advanced students and academics in the fields of sociology, cultural 
studies and religious studies.

Contents:

Foreword by Douglas Rushkoff
Introduction
1. The Difference Engine: Liberation and the Rave Imaginary - Graham St John
2. Ephemeral Spirit: Sacrificial Cyborg and Communal Soul - Hillegonda C. 
Rietveld
3. Rapturous Ruptures: the 'Instituant' Religious Experience of Rave - 
François Gauthier
4. 'Connectedness' and the Rave Experience: Rave as New Religious Movement? 
- Tim Olaveson
5. The Flesh of Raving: Merleau-Ponty and the 'Experience' of Ecstacy - 
James Landau
6. Entheogenic Dance Ecstasis: Cross-cultural Contexts - Des Tramacchi
7. The 'Natural High': Altered States, Flashbacks and Neural Tuning at 
Raves -  Melanie Takahashi
8. Selecting Ritual: DJ's Dancers and Liminality in Underground Dance Music 
- Morgan Gerard
9. Sounds of the London Underground: Gospel Music and Baptist Worship in 
the UK Garage Scene - Ciaran O'Hagan
10. Gamelan, Techno-Primitivism and the San Francisco Rave Scene - Gina 
Andrea Fatone
11. Techno Millennium: Dance, Ecology and Future Primitives - Graham St John
12. Global Nomads: Techno and New Age as Transnational Countercultures in 
Ibiza and Goa - Anthony D'Andrea
13. Hedonic Tantra: Golden Goa's Trance Transmission - Erik Davis
14. Goa Trance and Trance in Goa: Smooth Striations - Arun Saldanha
15. Dancing on Common Ground: Exploring the Sacred at Burning Man - Robert 
V. Kozinets and John F. Sherry, Jr.


The link to Routledge:

http://search.tandf.co.uk/bookscatalogue.asp?URL=https://ecommerce.tandf.co.uk/catalogue/DirectLink.asp?ResourceCentre=SEARCH&ContinentSelected=0&CountrySelected=0&USSelected=0&ChangeCountry=0&search_text=0415314496&SearchGroup=ISBN&results_order=ByTitle&querytext=rave%20culture&database






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net/harvest/

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV453DjFbUcOV000001dd@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 21 Nov 2003 17:56:17.0435 (UTC) FILETIME=[C328D6B0:01C3B058]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene

Some people sing about the girl//boy they love while others since about how
much they love god. Take any contemporary form of popular music and change
the lyrics to a religious theme and there ya go. This is why you see those
mega-massive christian prayer fests full of kids. Christian music has taken
the same marketing spin used to create boy bands and applied it to their
section of music.

What disturbs me more is the concept of a denomanational based rave. Give
that the whole point of raving was to express your freedom and make the
event what you want it to be I see something like religion going against
that ideal. Spirituality is what you make of it for yourself. When it comes
to events - you can have a christian god like experience or something more
zen buddhist. But the fact remains that parties aren't thrown under any
religious guise because at that point your freedom to make that event what
you want is already clouded.

I'm very much against religion being brought into events. Much like
seperation of church and state I feel there is a line that shouldn't be
crossed either. We all carry our own sense of spirituality with us. To each
their own and their freedom to experience a party without an organized
religious theme.

:: r ::

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "_ fable _" <fable4our@hotmail.com>

I have recently been dabbling in the concept of religion, and speaking to
people close to me.  I know this cool kat, he was really involved in the
scene in the early 90's.  He spoke of the full moon parties and love affair
parties and so on.  He is trying to find a medium between the rave scene and
christianity.  While I think this is awesome, I think it would be a hard
thing to accomplish, because I love swiggin on my hennessy and smokin on me
smoke when Im gettn down.  He said I would be surprised how many christians
do indulge in chronic or alcohol in moderation.  He had me listen to some
hiphop and downtempo that was made by christians...  I was like, DAMN!
These christian cats got flows!!  They weren't even flowing about jesus, the
bible, or anything, they were flowin about what underground hiphop heads be
flowin about.

I had this impression of what christian musician's would be like, and I was
totally wrong!  Although, I am just at the tip of the iceberg, I would like
to hear from you people about your understanding of christianity, music and
the rave scene.  Or not even christianity, just spirituality in general.

peace

fable....

Subject: Re: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene

"We all carry our own sense of spirituality with us. To each their own and 
their freedom to experience a party without an organized religious theme."

I totally agree with you.  I am new to this whole, 'spiritual music scene'.  
I thought it was interesting so I am trying to find out more.  I totally 
think a party or a rave should have a mix of every and any type of spiritual 
bodies, or un-spiritual bodies.  Spirituality shouldn't be the basis of 
music either, unless your feeling that topic at the time.  A christian 
friend of mine was saying that there are two types of christian music, one 
where they compose songs soley about god and christianity, and others where 
they speak about whatever they want, but they are christians.  The music 
that I liked was where they talked about whatever they wanted.  I think that 
artists who are openly christian get categorized into the christian music 
category simply because of their religion.  There are some sick artists out 
there, who you would never guess are categorized as christian music....

I dunno.  I can't imagine myself gettin down at a christian rave, simply 
because I wouldn't be able to have a pint of hennessy in my back pocket, but 
I'm willing to check it out.  It's all new to me!

fable....

ps...apologies for my rambling ; )




>From: "munkee" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
>To: "_ fable _" <fable4our@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene
>Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2003 09:56:25 -0800
>
>Some people sing about the girl//boy they love while others since about how
>much they love god. Take any contemporary form of popular music and change
>the lyrics to a religious theme and there ya go. This is why you see those
>mega-massive christian prayer fests full of kids. Christian music has taken
>the same marketing spin used to create boy bands and applied it to their
>section of music.
>
>What disturbs me more is the concept of a denomanational based rave. Give
>that the whole point of raving was to express your freedom and make the
>event what you want it to be I see something like religion going against
>that ideal. Spirituality is what you make of it for yourself. When it comes
>to events - you can have a christian god like experience or something more
>zen buddhist. But the fact remains that parties aren't thrown under any
>religious guise because at that point your freedom to make that event what
>you want is already clouded.
>
>I'm very much against religion being brought into events. Much like
>seperation of church and state I feel there is a line that shouldn't be
>crossed either. We all carry our own sense of spirituality with us. To each
>their own and their freedom to experience a party without an organized
>religious theme.
>
>:: r ::
>

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v606)

From: Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com>
Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2003 10:39:25 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.606)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene

When I was in Santa Fe last month, the only station that my hotel 
clock/radio could pick up was some Christian station, so I'd wake up 
to, er, "inspirational" music each A.M.  Believe me, it inspired me to 
get the hell out of bed and into the shower quite well!

One morning, though, I woke up to the same station playing some great 
EDM I hadn't heard before.  It was a bit trancey and had that whole 
"uplifiting" vibe (which I generally don't go for) but I have to say, 
it was some great wake-up music. Turns out it was some of the new stuff 
from a rising "club scene" within the religious music biz...

My first reaction to stuff like this is to ridicule it, etc. as some 
contrived way to recruit more youngin's into the church. But honestly, 
like the whole separation-of-Church-and-State thing brought up earlier, 
I don't think it matters where the music comes from or how its inspired 
- in the end, if it's good, enjoyable music (and you can dance to it!) 
then there's no reason not to listen to it.  Hell, it made my morning!

--
otavallai@
mac.com

Alouvc mwer neq? Gar, fro cwastnio! Fro cwastnio!

X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158

Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV44ixjnzi95H00000255@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 21 Nov 2003 18:40:48.0076 (UTC) FILETIME=[FAFC50C0:01C3B05E]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene

"...others where
they speak about whatever they want, but they are christians.  The music
that I liked was where they talked about whatever they wanted."

That's basically what all music is. Is Beck Jewish folk-rock-fusion music
just because he happens to be Jewish? I think when you're of a certain
faith, but your music doesn't blatantly reflect that faith it's just *music*
and nothing more. That same thing could be said about parties. You could
have a bunch of christian faith based kids throwing events, but that's not a
christian rave. It's when the group throwing the party imposes that
religious theme upon the attendees and themes the party in a religious
manner that an element of spiritual freedom is lost.

All I can say is any event I'm involved with will never, *never* be tainted
by a religious overtone. It's all about what you make of it and want it to
be spiritually for yourself.

:: r ::

>From: "munkee" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
>To: "_ fable _" <fable4our@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene
>Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2003 09:56:25 -0800
>
>Some people sing about the girl//boy they love while others since about how
>much they love god. Take any contemporary form of popular music and change
>the lyrics to a religious theme and there ya go. This is why you see those
>mega-massive christian prayer fests full of kids. Christian music has taken
>the same marketing spin used to create boy bands and applied it to their
>section of music.
>
>What disturbs me more is the concept of a denomanational based rave. Give
>that the whole point of raving was to express your freedom and make the
>event what you want it to be I see something like religion going against
>that ideal. Spirituality is what you make of it for yourself. When it comes
>to events - you can have a christian god like experience or something more
>zen buddhist. But the fact remains that parties aren't thrown under any
>religious guise because at that point your freedom to make that event what
>you want is already clouded.
>
>I'm very much against religion being brought into events. Much like
>seperation of church and state I feel there is a line that shouldn't be
>crossed either. We all carry our own sense of spirituality with us. To each
>their own and their freedom to experience a party without an organized
>religious theme.
>
>:: r ::
>
>----- Original Message -----
>From: "_ fable _" <fable4our@hotmail.com>

>I have recently been dabbling in the concept of religion, and speaking to
>people close to me.  I know this cool kat, he was really involved in the
>scene in the early 90's.  He spoke of the full moon parties and love affair
>parties and so on.  He is trying to find a medium between the rave scene
>and
>christianity.  While I think this is awesome, I think it would be a hard
>thing to accomplish, because I love swiggin on my hennessy and smokin on me
>smoke when Im gettn down.  He said I would be surprised how many christians
>do indulge in chronic or alcohol in moderation.  He had me listen to some
>hiphop and downtempo that was made by christians...  I was like, DAMN!
>These christian cats got flows!!  They weren't even flowing about jesus,
>the
>bible, or anything, they were flowin about what underground hiphop heads be
>flowin about.
>
>I had this impression of what christian musician's would be like, and I was
>totally wrong!  Although, I am just at the tip of the iceberg, I would like
>to hear from you people about your understanding of christianity, music and
>the rave scene.  Or not even christianity, just spirituality in general.
>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 10:40 AM 11/21/2003, munkee wrote:

>"...others where
>they speak about whatever they want, but they are christians.  The music
>that I liked was where they talked about whatever they wanted."
>
>That's basically what all music is. Is Beck Jewish folk-rock-fusion music
>just because he happens to be Jewish? I think when you're of a certain
>faith, but your music doesn't blatantly reflect that faith it's just *music*
>and nothing more. That same thing could be said about parties. You could
>have a bunch of christian faith based kids throwing events, but that's not a
>christian rave. It's when the group throwing the party imposes that
>religious theme upon the attendees and themes the party in a religious
>manner that an element of spiritual freedom is lost.

Wish I had more time to add value to this thread, but I'm working on 
another event tonight --  Leslie Ayres' birthday party.  Happy Birthday 
Leslie!!!

I personally have problems with any organized religion these days.  Most of 
my life I saw myself as an atheist or, at best, agnostic.  These days I 
have become much interested in "pagan" tribal experience in the context of 
music and dance: call this trance dancing;  experience of the "other" 
through group dance; or some sort of transcendent knowledge that some might 
define as "religious."   Ancient stuff.

This experience is available, I think, through various organized religious 
disciplines.  Raves, or communal dance in general, can be a valuable tool 
in the personal quest for self-knowledge, development of empathy for 
others, and achievement of some harmony with the rhythms of the universe 
around us.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net/harvest/

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"It is not the same to talk of the bulls as to be in the bullring."
-Spanish Proverb

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

> What disturbs me more is the concept of a
> denomanational based rave. Give

Well said- what's next?

Why not take things to a racial level?
Some would say that taking things to such extreme
levels to prove the point is a logical fallacy, but
it's still against the very principle.

Message-ID: <BAY8-F126fYmeE7pwgl000043d5@hotmail.com>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene

I would agree...I was raised as a Catholic, which "cured me" of getting 
involved with any contemporary organized religion. However, as of late, I've 
been delving into the ancient Egyptian culture, and finding some interesting 
things about their "religion" which wasn't quite what it is made out to be. 
Their whole culture was one living, breathing entity. Religion wasn't just 
religion, it was art, music, philosophy, etc., as was the case for their 
architecture, art, music, way of life...etc. Everything was inter-related. 
It was simultaneously spiritual and mundane. Everything and everyone were 
very "in tune" with everything else and everyone else. They used 
hallucinogens and other intoxicants to expand their consciousness, as well 
as used ritual to commune with each other and their "gods". This might 
explain why their civilisation was so far advanced. Either way, they weren't 
the barbarous people most academia makes them out to be.....

M-

pardon my babbling....

>At 10:40 AM 11/21/2003, munkee wrote:
>
>>"...others where
>>they speak about whatever they want, but they are christians.  The music
>>that I liked was where they talked about whatever they wanted."
>>
>>That's basically what all music is. Is Beck Jewish folk-rock-fusion music
>>just because he happens to be Jewish? I think when you're of a certain
>>faith, but your music doesn't blatantly reflect that faith it's just 
>>*music*
>>and nothing more. That same thing could be said about parties. You could
>>have a bunch of christian faith based kids throwing events, but that's not 
>>a
>>christian rave. It's when the group throwing the party imposes that
>>religious theme upon the attendees and themes the party in a religious
>>manner that an element of spiritual freedom is lost.
>
>Wish I had more time to add value to this thread, but I'm working on 
>another event tonight --  Leslie Ayres' birthday party.  Happy Birthday 
>Leslie!!!
>
>I personally have problems with any organized religion these days.  Most of 
>my life I saw myself as an atheist or, at best, agnostic.  These days I 
>have become much interested in "pagan" tribal experience in the context of 
>music and dance: call this trance dancing;  experience of the "other" 
>through group dance; or some sort of transcendent knowledge that some might 
>define as "religious."   Ancient stuff.
>
>This experience is available, I think, through various organized religious 
>disciplines.  Raves, or communal dance in general, can be a valuable tool 
>in the personal quest for self-knowledge, development of empathy for 
>others, and achievement of some harmony with the rhythms of the universe 
>around us.
>
>Love,
>
>Apollo
>

LoL... so I end up @ POW & the Jungle night that stopped a few weeks ago starterd again... it was Awesome... but I didn't go in...

So I walked over 2 Bad Kitty & right away I saw Seraphim lookin' Sharp in this dull red light that was shinning from above her, electro clash was playing in the back ground... la la la... naw.. but it was Groovy seein' her again & wee always have alot 2 talk about when we C each other as of lately!

BUt it was CooL 'cause the happy Hour DJ was still spinning this eclectic mixture of beats ranging from 80's music 2 House 2 Electro... yeah... it could probably be comparable 2 an AndyW set... LoL... jk...

Then Seraphim went on & totally started off spinning The Go-Go's "We Got The Beat" & ooooooh.. she totally went 80's,,,,, yummy! Although I couldn't stay 2 long & the last song I did stay 4 was "Don't You Want Me Baby" by Human League... I mean.. I was there 4 like 1/2 hr more or less, but man.. it was still fun there!!  I mean... I meet the Grooviest people when I'm there & Hello 2Day... my Favorite BAr Tender is back from Vacation *MoHa"...

I mean.. really... this place is jus' so fun 2 kick it on a Thursday night... what's even more Groovy is that there's art on the walls that'4 sale!!!  Man... if I ever get enough money while that painting I want is still on sale... hmmmm... I may get it!!

I mean like, I could tell that the fun jus' totally started jus' as I wa like about 2 leave... but ya know.. .bart sucks... Hello 2Day...

BUt I still had a fun time!

Speaking of cat's, is it still possible 4 cats 2 still have sex even after they're fixed?  I coulda sworn I heard my cat having sex lastnight in the bushes... I mean... I know that's a mondo lame question... but ya know... I seriously have 2 know if they will be any harm from it 'cause ya know... Pheobe's fixed & she's hmmmm... she's like me... she's confused alot!  LoL


Take Care,
Peace-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] nrr: 10 of the worst pick up lines

1. "What's your sign?"

2. "Pardon me, I seem to have lost my phone number, can I borrow yours?"

3. "You must be a broom because you're sweeping me off my feet."

4. "Do you have a licence? Because you're driving me crazy."

5. "I gotta thirst and baby, you look like my Gatorade."

6. "Are you lost? Because heaven's a long way from here."

7. "Are you religious? Because you're the answer to all my prayers."

8. "Can I take your picture? I want Santa to know exactly what I want for Christmas."

9. "Do you believe in love at first sight or should I walk by again?"

10. "Well, here I am. What are your other two wishes?"

On Fri, 21 Nov 2003, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
-&e->I would agree...I was raised as a Catholic, which "cured me" of
-&e->getting involved with any contemporary organized religion. However,
-&e->as of late, I've been delving into the ancient Egyptian culture, and
-&e->finding some interesting things about their "religion" which wasn't
-&e->quite what it is made out to be.  Their whole culture was one living,
-&e->breathing entity. Religion wasn't just religion, it was art, music,
-&e->philosophy, etc., as was the case for their architecture, art, music,
-&e->way of life...etc. Everything was inter-related.  It was
-&e->simultaneously spiritual and mundane. Everything and everyone were
-&e->very "in tune" with everything else and everyone else. They used
-&e->hallucinogens and other intoxicants to expand their consciousness, as
-&e->well as used ritual to commune with each other and their "gods". This
-&e->might explain why their civilisation was so far advanced. Either way,
-&e->they weren't the barbarous people most academia makes them out to
-&e->be.....

When your society's greatest legacy was built almost exclusively by
ruthless, high fatality slave labor, you get the barbarian label.  It's
just one of my rules.

andyw

On Fri, 21 Nov 2003, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
-&e->I would agree...I was raised as a Catholic, which "cured me" of
-&e->getting involved with any contemporary organized religion. However,
-&e->as of late, I've been delving into the ancient Egyptian culture,
and -&e->finding some interesting things about their "religion" which
wasn't -&e->quite what it is made out to be.  Their whole culture was
one living, -&e->breathing entity. Religion wasn't just religion, it was
art, music, -&e->philosophy, etc., as was the case for their
architecture, art, music, -&e->way of life...etc. Everything was
inter-related.  It was -&e->simultaneously spiritual and mundane.
Everything and everyone were -&e->very "in tune" with everything else
and everyone else. They used -&e->hallucinogens and other intoxicants to
expand their consciousness, as -&e->well as used ritual to commune with
each other and their "gods". This -&e->might explain why their
civilisation was so far advanced. Either way, -&e->they weren't the
barbarous people most academia makes them out to -&e->be.....

When your society's greatest legacy was built almost exclusively by
ruthless, high fatality slave labor, you get the barbarian label.  It's
just one of my rules.

andyw

actually, i followed the discussion with interest from dc, so there was
relevance beyond the sfr community.  thank you for all the various points
of view.  definitely fodder for thought.   :)

big helloooooo to Van Mundegaarde!  miss ya on this coast!

in any case, just got this from my favorite band in the world who is from
your new neck o' the woods!  woot!

respectfully,
mary :)


Green Day Announces re-issue of "39/Smooth" on January 27th 2004

Green Day and Lookout! Records and pleased to announce the re-issue
of their first album "39/Smooth". This special deluxe edition has
been re-mastered so the sound quality is better than ever.  It also
features over 20 minutes of live performances from 1991 as well as
tons of vintage photos, handwritten lyrics by Billie Joe and
original flyers.  It also includes a  live radio performance and
interview from 1991, and like the original CD version features the
band's first two seven inch EPs "1000 Hours" from 1989 and "Slappy"
from 1990.

For more information go to http://www.lookoutrecords.com/greenday and
for a free MP3 of "409 In Your Coffeemaker" go to
http://www.lookoutrecords.com/sounds


This record is for you, the Green Day fan.  We hope you like it and
be sure to be in line on Janurary 27th!!!!


http://greenday.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene

That common misperception of Egyptian culture was abandoned quite a few 
years ago ;)

Yes, they most likely had slaves, but not nearly the ammount that was 
previously thought, nor were they forced to build ANYTHING as is the biggest 
misconception (all building of structures was run like any modern day 
national project, with hired, skilled, PAID laborers). They also had say in 
politics, etc.
"Slaves" in Egypt were more often than not, assimilated peoples of conquered 
nations....

M-

>>-&e->I would agree...I was raised as a Catholic, which "cured me" of
>>-&e->getting involved with any contemporary organized religion. However,
>>-&e->as of late, I've been delving into the ancient Egyptian culture, and
>>-&e->finding some interesting things about their "religion" which wasn't
>>-&e->quite what it is made out to be.  Their whole culture was one living,
>>-&e->breathing entity. Religion wasn't just religion, it was art, music,
>>-&e->philosophy, etc., as was the case for their architecture, art, music,
>>-&e->way of life...etc. Everything was inter-related.  It was
>>-&e->simultaneously spiritual and mundane. Everything and everyone were
>>-&e->very "in tune" with everything else and everyone else. They used
>>-&e->hallucinogens and other intoxicants to expand their consciousness, as
>>-&e->well as used ritual to commune with each other and their "gods". This
>>-&e->might explain why their civilisation was so far advanced. Either way,
>>-&e->they weren't the barbarous people most academia makes them out to
>>-&e->be.....
>>
>>When your society's greatest legacy was built almost exclusively by
>>ruthless, high fatality slave labor, you get the barbarian label.  It's
>>just one of my rules.
>>
>>andyw

    I realized that it's been a long time since I've posted to SFR when =
it wasn't a BSP about a party I was throwing or helping with. I wanted =
to take the time to say thank you to SFRaves and to the rave community =
in general. It was only about 2 1/2 years ago that I discovered that I =
am a raver, and my life has improved dramatically in that time as I have =
grown into the person that I am now. I'd like to thank every stranger at =
a party who didn't care about my color, my age or my job, and who talked =
to me as person. I've gotten a lot of love out of this scene, and I try =
to give it back whenever I can. Thank you all, and keep on dancing!

Love,

Happy :-)

"A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs

Subject: [sfraves] Godskitchen venue is off the hook!

We just returned from the Avalon Ballroom for a bite to eat. All I can say
is.....

Gianni, the Avalon and Godskitchen have done an AMAZING thing to this
venue!!

Can we say ALICE IN WONDERLAND???????????? This night is going to be off the
hook! They've been working on the production since last night after driving
the the Godskitchen truck from Vegas for a long 10 hour drive!

I hope that everyone can make it down for this event! Everything is top
notch! The props, the laser, the lighting, the whole feel of the place. When
we walked in, we felt like we had stepped back into the Renaissance period!

The venue is at the corner of Van Ness and Sutter in the City, and the event
begins at 7pm tonight! If you're 18 or older, then it's on for you. They've
got bars upstairs for the 21+. The info line is at 415.820.3904. You can
check out the online info at http://www.mostwantedna.com/gk.

See you tonight!! Fergie is going to be awesome! :) MODA

Subject: Re: [sfraves]Christian Rave/Music Scene

I think the point missed here is that Christians aren't seeking to create 
TAZ's open to everyone to express their freedoms.  They're partying with 
their God in a new way - one which follows modern music trends.  I applaud 
it.  Make it Racial.. make it religion based, whatever, it's still logical 
that people that cling to an ideology can want to celebrate, by 
themselves.  Do you think Mason's and Moose Lodge members don't throw 
private parties, that conform to their ideals?  What it be any different if 
they decided to throw an event with electronic music instead?


sarilion

SISTER SF TICKET GIVE AWAY!
FIRST 5 PEOPLE TO RESPOND, RECEIVE A
FREE PAIR OF TICKETS TO DRAGNET! EMAIL US

 


Fri. Nov. 21st: SISTER SF presents DRAGNET! 
This is it: our long awaited-for drag event for 2003! 

Our chance to get our favorite male DJs to tag team with us in drag. Men DJing in dresses. An annual event. 
Why? Because we like men. In dresses.
And we promised them you wouldn't laugh! 



 


Seraphim vs. Felix the Dog (GS, K-9 Unit)

Polywog vs. Dr. Lung (theBrainTree, theF*ckerMagnet)

Melyss vs. DJ Seven (Pink Mammoth, Blue)

Subject: [sfraves] Mayans (was Re: Christian Rave/Music Scene)

	Hmm... when I was in Mexico looking at Mayan ruins earlier this year, 
I read a number of pamphlets and exhibits and such about Mayan history 
and culture. There was ample material illustrating the warlike and 
barbaric (i.e. bloody) nature of that society, but nothing (at least 
that I remember) suggesting that the Toltecs were responsible for these 
qualities, or that the Mayans were originally peaceful. They did build 
some impressive temples though! I was most impressed by the beauty of 
the ruins at Palenque. There's also a local culture in that area of 
taking hallucinogenic mushrooms, which grow thereabouts.

Groove on,
						<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Mayans (was Re: Christian Rave/Music Scene)

when i visited chichen itza in 2000, the local tour guide showed us the 
part that was built before the toltecs moved in from the north and 
merged, or more or less took over their culture.  before they came, 
there was merely a few buildings and an astronomical observatory, which 
is one of the oldest buildings.  after the merging, which is symbolized 
by the pillars in the temple of the warriors, is when he said people 
were sacrificed into the natural wells that are all around the area.  
probably not as brutal as what the aztecs did, but it's a start.

btw, i've never been to palenque, but el castillo at chichen itza is 
amazing if you climb to the top; it's obvious that some of the footage 
from the original star wars movie was filmed down at one of these 
temples, namely the scene where the millenium falcon flies into the 
rebel base on the moon where they make their stand off with the death 
star.

-d

Subject: [sfraves] .: Dirtbox Radio Tonight : 11/23 : Mugzy : Kauz : simulcast time!
 :.


What's up guys and gals!  Tonight is Sunday, and therefore Dirtbox Radio
will be taking to the muffuckin airwaves!

Tonight marks the first in what'll hopefully be a long tradition of
simulcasting over Jungletrain.net and now Destroyer.net.  Just in case you
didn't know, Destroyer's doin their thing here in DC, and we're glad to
team up wif 'em.

The guest DJs for tonight will be DJ Kauz and the one like Mugzy.  Kauz is
one of our boys, he's done his thing with the Deez Beatz parties in
Bethesda, and hosts a show of his own, every Friday from 8-11pm (CST) on
Midwest DNB's netcast station.  Hit up www.mw-dnb.com for more info, yo.
Syncopation crew's own Mugzy will be with us as well tonight.  Mugzy rips
decks like a champ, and throws a couple phat ass parties in the Baltimore
area, Staccato & Syncopation (one of my favorite joints).  Staccato runs
every tuesday @ the Mojo Lounge in Balmer, and Syncopation should be back
with us soon at a new location 'round the Towson area.  So yeah, both are
tight cats and put in work, so y'all tune in and catch 'em live tonight.

For audio links, webcam, and chatroom, just point your browser towards
http://dirtboxradio.com/listen.html

Tonight's lineup is as follows:
07-08pm EST - Intro Jammy wif ODJ & Jerel
08-09:30pm EST - Mugzy *
09:30-11pm EST - Kauz *
11-2ish pm EST - Outro Jammy wif ODJ, Jerel, and possibly s'more Dirtbox
Kru

* times might be switched... stay tuned to www.dirtboxradio.com for
up-to-the-motherfuckin-minute updates.

Big shout out to Destroyer for havin' us, only good things to come...

... and if you're in the area and not listening to Dirtbox, get your ass
over to Seventh Day Soul @ South Beach in Bethesda for some hot Sunday
night jams.

Easy,
Jackson
(ps - props to Camille, Alexis, Dan, Chet, and the rest of the crew that
made last night a blast.)

Subject: [sfraves] nrr: Mystery Skin Disease in Daly City

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C3B1A2.081AAC90
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I just came across this. . .

It so sucks to be sick with something that absolutely no one knows about
or believes. Thus no research, no remedies, no doctors, no help. . .

I feel for em. . . could you imagine how much faith and will it would
take to go thru some unimaginable illness day after day and all you have
to look forward to is for somehow something happens that makes you
better, even tho that was basically all on you. . . cuz dumbass doctors
are so closed minded. They're pretty strong people to deal with all the
various issues surrounding something like that. Like the way they feel
about themselves, the way others look at them, not to mention the pain,
discomfort, etc they constantly deal with.

            Hopefully the news article will bring some attention to it.

 

Take care all

 

aK

 

"Mystery Skin Disease in Daly City"
 


  

Westlake residents complain of mystery disease 

By Kate Williamson
Of The Examiner Staff
kwilliamson@examiner.com
Published on Monday, November 17, 2003 

DALY CITY -- Some residents of Westlake Village Apartments have
complained to the county that they have a mysterious skin infection, but
feel they are left on their own in coping with the outbreak. 
Following the notification to the San Mateo County Health Services
Agency, county officials recently ordered the complex to seal up holes
that may allow rodents into the units. But it is unclear if that will
combat the infection, or even if the mice and rats are responsible. 
Residents of four apartments at 205 Palmcrest Drive interviewed for this
article feared to be named, suspecting reprisal. They reported -- and in
some cases, showed -- an ongoing skin condition. 
Primarily non-English speakers, the residents said their landlord and
officials have cast them adrift. 
"This thing started in December of last year," said one father of two
young girls, all of whom have been infected. 
Under his armpit, he displayed a wound near a rash, the afterimage of a
golf-ball-size boil that was cut open and drained of liquid at an
emergency room Nov. 9. 
The boils start out smaller, as spots that resemble bug bites at the
center of a pale, discolored ring, he said. His two young daughters and
his wife both had the marks Nov. 11. Those bites grow until they are
filled with pus and the victim develops a fever, he said. He has had to
stay home from work with the illness, making it difficult for him to
work enough to afford the family's rent. 
Cutting the boils open is the only thing that cures them, he said. He
was told he developed a bacterial infection because he is a hairy man,
but he does not know how his smooth-skinned girls could also have the
problem, he said 
"I passed every test. I don't have nothing," he said. 
Research on several medical Web sites revealed that the symptoms are
similar to furuncles, or boils, caused by bacteria or fungal infection
and can be linked to diabetes. 
Residents in two other apartments also told The Examiner they had
contracted the infection. 
The San Mateo County Health Services Agency was alerted to the infection
at the complex in October, said agency representative Beverly Thames. 
The nurses spoke with a doctor who treated one of the residents and
determined the infection was not a "reportable" communicable disease. 
"I would love it if one of the docs would evaluate them and, if they
feel there's a significant problem, do a culture," said county public
health doctor Sam Stebbins. "We need that information from the
practitioners." 
Stebbins recommended that anyone afflicted with the boils come to the
North County Health Center in Daly City. Emergency rooms tend to be
harried, Stebbins said. He added that contagious bacterial infections
are rare, relying as they do on skin-to-skin contact. 
"We haven't closed the book on it," he said. 
Some residents fear their infection is related to the ongoing rodent
problem in the building, saying they did not have the disease before a
particularly bad mouse infestation earlier this year. 
The county environmental health division inspected the property Oct. 23.
They found one dead rat mite and a live one in two apartments, but they
are not likely to be connected to the illness. 
The residents' symptoms are inconsistent with mite or fleabites, said
Environmental Services Director Dean Peterson. 
"Rarely is a bite going to cause a bacterial infection unless you
scratch it and open it," he said. 
"The only time anything was done was when the health department came and
the building inspector came," said one woman. 
A Westlake representative did not return calls by press time. 
With nobody taking responsibility to coordinate tackling the infection,
residents remain frustrated. 
"We are looking for somebody to help us," said the man with the cut
beneath his arm. 

bvh


------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C3B1A2.081AAC90--

Quoting aK_ <aK@Hard-grooves.com>:

> I just came across this. . .
> 
> It so sucks to be sick with something that absolutely no one knows about
> or believes. Thus no research, no remedies, no doctors, no help. . .
> 
> I feel for em. . . could you imagine how much faith and will it would
> take to go thru some unimaginable illness day after day and all you have
> to look forward to is for somehow something happens that makes you
> better, even tho that was basically all on you. . . cuz dumbass doctors
> are so closed minded. They're pretty strong people to deal with all the
> various issues surrounding something like that. Like the way they feel
> about themselves, the way others look at them, not to mention the pain,
> discomfort, etc they constantly deal with.
> 
>             Hopefully the news article will bring some attention to it.
> 
>  
> 
> Take care all
> 
>  
> 
> aK
> 
>  
> 
> "Mystery Skin Disease in Daly City"
>  
> 
> 
>   
> 
> Westlake residents complain of mystery disease 
> 
> By Kate Williamson
> Of The Examiner Staff
> kwilliamson@examiner.com
> Published on Monday, November 17, 2003 
> 
> DALY CITY -- Some residents of Westlake Village Apartments have
> complained to the county that they have a mysterious skin infection, but
> feel they are left on their own in coping with the outbreak. 
> Following the notification to the San Mateo County Health Services
> Agency, county officials recently ordered the complex to seal up holes
> that may allow rodents into the units. But it is unclear if that will
> combat the infection, or even if the mice and rats are responsible. 
> Residents of four apartments at 205 Palmcrest Drive interviewed for this
> article feared to be named, suspecting reprisal. They reported -- and in
> some cases, showed -- an ongoing skin condition. 
> Primarily non-English speakers, the residents said their landlord and
> officials have cast them adrift. 
> "This thing started in December of last year," said one father of two
> young girls, all of whom have been infected. 
> Under his armpit, he displayed a wound near a rash, the afterimage of a
> golf-ball-size boil that was cut open and drained of liquid at an
> emergency room Nov. 9. 
> The boils start out smaller, as spots that resemble bug bites at the
> center of a pale, discolored ring, he said. His two young daughters and
> his wife both had the marks Nov. 11. Those bites grow until they are
> filled with pus and the victim develops a fever, he said. He has had to
> stay home from work with the illness, making it difficult for him to
> work enough to afford the family's rent. 
> Cutting the boils open is the only thing that cures them, he said. He
> was told he developed a bacterial infection because he is a hairy man,
> but he does not know how his smooth-skinned girls could also have the
> problem, he said 
> "I passed every test. I don't have nothing," he said. 
> Research on several medical Web sites revealed that the symptoms are
> similar to furuncles, or boils, caused by bacteria or fungal infection
> and can be linked to diabetes. 
> Residents in two other apartments also told The Examiner they had
> contracted the infection. 
> The San Mateo County Health Services Agency was alerted to the infection
> at the complex in October, said agency representative Beverly Thames. 
> The nurses spoke with a doctor who treated one of the residents and
> determined the infection was not a "reportable" communicable disease. 
> "I would love it if one of the docs would evaluate them and, if they
> feel there's a significant problem, do a culture," said county public
> health doctor Sam Stebbins. "We need that information from the
> practitioners." 
> Stebbins recommended that anyone afflicted with the boils come to the
> North County Health Center in Daly City. Emergency rooms tend to be
> harried, Stebbins said. He added that contagious bacterial infections
> are rare, relying as they do on skin-to-skin contact. 
> "We haven't closed the book on it," he said. 
> Some residents fear their infection is related to the ongoing rodent
> problem in the building, saying they did not have the disease before a
> particularly bad mouse infestation earlier this year. 
> The county environmental health division inspected the property Oct. 23.
> They found one dead rat mite and a live one in two apartments, but they
> are not likely to be connected to the illness. 
> The residents' symptoms are inconsistent with mite or fleabites, said
> Environmental Services Director Dean Peterson. 
> "Rarely is a bite going to cause a bacterial infection unless you
> scratch it and open it," he said. 
> "The only time anything was done was when the health department came and
> the building inspector came," said one woman. 
> A Westlake representative did not return calls by press time. 
> With nobody taking responsibility to coordinate tackling the infection,
> residents remain frustrated. 
> "We are looking for somebody to help us," said the man with the cut
> beneath his arm. 
> 
> bvh

From sfraves-return-108435-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Nov 24 20:35:29 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-108435-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 9595 invoked by uid 1103); 24 Nov 2003 20:35:29 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 9581 invoked from network); 24 Nov 2003 20:35:29 -0000
Message-ID: <20031124203526.22744.qmail@web40811.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 24 Nov 2003 12:35:26 -0800 (PST)
From: s d <suchagoodkid@yahoo.com>
To: aK_ <aK@Hard-grooves.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <000001c3b1e5$163dec90$94f156d1@sziggo>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: Mystery Skin Disease in Daly City

there has been a similar health epidemic in san
francisco, for a year or so.  the health dept knows
about it, it has been linked to poor hygiene, weak
immune systems, drug use, malnutrition, and similar
conditions.
it's an abscess of staph infection in most cases, is
extremely painful, and can be very dangerous depending
on location of infection and time left untreated.  it
is similar to flesh eating bacteria.  they keep
sweeping it under the rug because they assume its the
poor and the drug users.  that's often not the case.
it has been through the gay community, the dance
community, drug community, low income, ....
doctors don't know what to do with it, except
prescribe a massive dose of super antibiotics, blaming
the abscesses on 'highly evolved strains of staph'. 
most often it's misdiagnosed or left untreated at
first, because doctors can't narrow down the exact
cause.  the center for disease control is monitoring
it closely, but can't pin it down. many cases were 
supposedly related to meth use, putting 'dirty' street
drugs into an already weakened system from drug use.
everyone carries staph in and on them, but it is
opportunistic to weak systems, and more mutated
strains can be passed on by shared drug paraphenalia
and/or physical contact.
thanks for posting that info, people need to be aware
of what's out there...

> feel there's a significant problem, do a culture,"
> said county public
> health doctor Sam Stebbins. "We need that
> information from the
> practitioners." 
> Stebbins recommended that anyone afflicted with the
> boils come to the
> North County Health Center in Daly City. Emergency
> rooms tend to be
> harried, Stebbins said. He added that contagious
> bacterial infections
> are rare, relying as they do on skin-to-skin
> contact. 
> "We haven't closed the book on it," he said. 
> Some residents fear their infection is related to
> the ongoing rodent
> problem in the building, saying they did not have
> the disease before a
> particularly bad mouse infestation earlier this
> year. 
> The county environmental health division inspected
> the property Oct. 23.
> They found one dead rat mite and a live one in two
> apartments, but they
> are not likely to be connected to the illness. 
> The residents' symptoms are inconsistent with mite
> or fleabites, said
> Environmental Services Director Dean Peterson. 
> "Rarely is a bite going to cause a bacterial
> infection unless you
> scratch it and open it," he said.

> department came and

> press time.

> beneath his arm.

From: s d <suchagoodkid@yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 24 Nov 2003 12:35:26 -0800 (PST)
To: aK_ <aK@Hard-grooves.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: Mystery Skin Disease in Daly City

> there has been a similar health epidemic in san
> francisco, for a year or so.  the health dept knows
> about it, it has been linked to poor hygiene, weak
> immune systems, drug use, malnutrition, and similar
> conditions.
> it's an abscess of staph infection in most cases, is
> extremely painful, and can be very dangerous depending
> on location of infection and time left untreated.  it
> is similar to flesh eating bacteria.  they keep
> sweeping it under the rug because they assume its the
> poor and the drug users.  that's often not the case.
> it has been through the gay community, the dance
> community, drug community, low income, ....
> doctors don't know what to do with it, except
> prescribe a massive dose of super antibiotics, blaming
> the abscesses on 'highly evolved strains of staph'. 
> most often it's misdiagnosed or left untreated at
> first, because doctors can't narrow down the exact
> cause.  the center for disease control is monitoring
> it closely, but can't pin it down. many cases were 
> supposedly related to meth use, putting 'dirty' street
> drugs into an already weakened system from drug use.
> everyone carries staph in and on them, but it is
> opportunistic to weak systems, and more mutated
> strains can be passed on by shared drug paraphenalia
> and/or physical contact.
> thanks for posting that info, people need to be aware
> of what's out there...
> 
> 
> --- aK_ <aK@Hard-grooves.com> wrote:

> > absolutely no one knows about

> > that makes you

> > cuz dumbass doctors
> > are so closed minded. They're pretty strong people
> > to deal with all the

> > to mention the pain,

> > aK

> >  
> > 
> > "Mystery Skin Disease in Daly City"
> >  
> > 
> > 
> >   
> > 
> > Westlake residents complain of mystery disease 
> > 
> > By Kate Williamson
> > Of The Examiner Staff
> > kwilliamson@examiner.com
> > Published on Monday, November 17, 2003 
> > 
> > DALY CITY -- Some residents of Westlake Village
> > Apartments have
> > complained to the county that they have a mysterious
> > skin infection, but
> > feel they are left on their own in coping with the
> > outbreak. 
> > Following the notification to the San Mateo County
> > Health Services
> > Agency, county officials recently ordered the
> > complex to seal up holes
> > that may allow rodents into the units. But it is
> > unclear if that will
> > combat the infection, or even if the mice and rats
> > are responsible. 
> > Residents of four apartments at 205 Palmcrest Drive
> > interviewed for this
> > article feared to be named, suspecting reprisal.
> > They reported -- and in
> > some cases, showed -- an ongoing skin condition. 
> > Primarily non-English speakers, the residents said
> > their landlord and
> > officials have cast them adrift. 
> > "This thing started in December of last year," said
> > one father of two
> > young girls, all of whom have been infected. 
> > Under his armpit, he displayed a wound near a rash,
> > the afterimage of a
> > golf-ball-size boil that was cut open and drained of
> > liquid at an
> > emergency room Nov. 9. 
> > The boils start out smaller, as spots that resemble
> > bug bites at the
> > center of a pale, discolored ring, he said. His two
> > young daughters and
> > his wife both had the marks Nov. 11. Those bites
> > grow until they are
> > filled with pus and the victim develops a fever, he
> > said. He has had to
> > stay home from work with the illness, making it
> > difficult for him to
> > work enough to afford the family's rent. 
> > Cutting the boils open is the only thing that cures
> > them, he said. He
> > was told he developed a bacterial infection because
> > he is a hairy man,
> > but he does not know how his smooth-skinned girls
> > could also have the
> > problem, he said 
> > "I passed every test. I don't have nothing," he
> > said. 
> > Research on several medical Web sites revealed that
> > the symptoms are
> > similar to furuncles, or boils, caused by bacteria
> > or fungal infection
> > and can be linked to diabetes. 
> > Residents in two other apartments also told The
> > Examiner they had
> > contracted the infection. 
> > The San Mateo County Health Services Agency was
> > alerted to the infection
> > at the complex in October, said agency
> > representative Beverly Thames. 
> > The nurses spoke with a doctor who treated one of
> > the residents and
> > determined the infection was not a "reportable"
> > communicable disease. 
> > "I would love it if one of the docs would evaluate
> > them and, if they
> > feel there's a significant problem, do a culture,"
> > said county public
> > health doctor Sam Stebbins. "We need that
> > information from the
> > practitioners." 
> > Stebbins recommended that anyone afflicted with the
> > boils come to the
> > North County Health Center in Daly City. Emergency
> > rooms tend to be
> > harried, Stebbins said. He added that contagious
> > bacterial infections
> > are rare, relying as they do on skin-to-skin
> > contact. 
> > "We haven't closed the book on it," he said. 
> > Some residents fear their infection is related to
> > the ongoing rodent
> > problem in the building, saying they did not have
> > the disease before a
> > particularly bad mouse infestation earlier this
> > year. 
> > The county environmental health division inspected
> > the property Oct. 23.
> > They found one dead rat mite and a live one in two
> > apartments, but they
> > are not likely to be connected to the illness. 
> > The residents' symptoms are inconsistent with mite
> > or fleabites, said
> > Environmental Services Director Dean Peterson.

> > infection unless you

Date: Mon, 24 Nov 2003 14:09:41 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY8-F122xPTi68KtBs0000cce4@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 24 Nov 2003 22:09:42.0587 (UTC) FILETIME=[A96028B0:01C3B2D7]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] RR: AMNESIA review (11.22.03)

Rolled on down to AMNESIA to catch a little mo' breakbeat goodness on 
Saturday night.

1st off, I like small places, and love breaks, so this (monthly?) shindig is 
a godsend to me. The only thing that could improve it, is if they served 
actual liquor, and not just beer. Thank god for the $3 shots of Underberg 
(or whatever it's called...Jaegermeisters beefy cousin). Either there was 
some sort of special going on, or the bartenders were just being fucking 
cool, cuz I didn't pay more than $4 for a pint all night, and I had a few 
pricier beverages.

Now on to the tunes...

Once again Donna Matrix kept the flow going all night. She started off a 
littlle of the slower side of things, but when she got back on the decks 
later in the night, she straight ripped it!! There was one other cat on the 
bill that impressed me quite a bit this time around...his name is Alexander 
(that's all I caught), and he seems to stick more to the Freq Nasty, 
breakstep, ragga kinda sound. It's done very well though. High energy 
through and through.

The other two dj's seemed to be having problems either with the mixer, or 
with the setup in general. They didn't play poorly really, but there were 
some "let's just flick the fader over here and hope no one notices" mixes 
going on.

All in all, I had a fucking blast. Heard great tunes, drank good beers, and 
relaxed.

Looking forward to the next one.....

Marc(O)
*THWAP!*//Substructure
DC/MD/VA/CA
deep.funky.techy.tribal.progressive.nuskool.beats&bass
AIM: OPKing138

GOOD BEATS 
FRIENDS & FAMILY 
ALL AGES 
NO COVER / DONATIONS ACCEPTED!
--------------------------------------------------
 FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 28th , 2003 
-------------------------------------------------- 
TIME: ( 7:00 PM - MIDNIGHT ) 
-------------------------------------------------- 
DRUM & BASS // BREAKBEATS // DANCEHALL // HOUSE // WHATEVER 

WITH DJ's: 

D J T A O (Insomniac, www.bassrush.com , UMS), Davis [Drum & Bass]
+
M I K E Y J , (Sacramento) [Drum & Bass]
+
D J H O J ( www.djhoj.com ) , San Francisco [Progressive House & Breaks]
+
R I S I N G S U N (Resonance) , Sacramento [Drum & Bass]
+
G . O . S . T . (Resonance, Turntable Tuesdays), Davis [Drum & Bass]
+ 
More TBA ... 
----------------------------------------

Directions from Sac: 

80 West 
Exit Olive Dr. 
At the stoplight, GO RIGHT 
Then follow directions below dotted line 

Directions from SF: 

80 East 
Exit Richards Blvd. (Downtown Davis) 
GO RIGHT, 
--------------------------------------------- 

You will be on Richards Blvd., 
after the tunnel, at the light, GO LEFT 
Now you will be on 1st ST. 
Go down 3 blocks, 
At the stopsign, GO RIGHT 
You will be on B ST. 

Event is 2 doors down on the right at: 122 B ST., Plenty of parking in the lot to the right of the Cafe, or around the neighborhood. Please be respectful of the neighbors and keep your noise levels down when outside. Thank you. 

Early arrival is strongly suggested. 

See you on the dancefloor...

Hey whutup

You can get pretty sick lil led sets from a lot of of auto perf dealers
on ebay. . .theres a lot of diff colors, and the "spot light" kind of
effect for interior sets and all might be an improvement too. 
You can get them from like less than a dollar for just a hyperwhite led,
to like 10-$40 for a lil interior kit or something like that. 

You could probably get diff shades of blue, purple, yellow, hyperwhite,
red, I think some guys also have like hyperblue n all. . 

Itd be cool to install a couple under the platter too. . . thatd be a
groovy effect. . .

: )

aK

Subject: Re: [sfraves]nrr: DJs: Turntable LEDs

I will have to jump in and say that Don is a great guy and knows what he's
doing. If you're not comfortable modifying your rather expensive equipment I
suggest you let Don handle that for you. A lot less headache and you know
your beloved gear is going to come back to you in working order. =)

On the LED topic if you're really saavy you could use the RGB led's and with
a simple controller be able to have 256 colors selectable. That's how those
color change car decks work... There are also true UV (blacklight) LEDs but
they aren't cheap. About $20/ea. I'm going to be installing them in a car
application for instrumentation illumination for the needles. Why - just
because I'm an electronics geek.

:: r ::

On Wednesday - 11/26, BaSSCamp will unite San Francisco in the spirit of : 
Charity, Community, Celebration and Dance!

Online flier: (www.BassCampSF.com)

Wednesday 11/26/03, the night before Thanksgiving
550 Barneveld, SF CA
10:00pm-5:00am
$10 with 2 cans of food to benefit Hunters Point Food bank
$15 admission

BaSSCamp the folks that brought SummerCamp & SnowCamp to San Francisco

100% of proceeds are donated to send at risk kids to SummerCamp!

3 Sound Systems and 3 rooms: Deep & Progressive House, Breaks & Funky Chill 
+ Special Live Set Djs representing 13 of San Franciscos leading music 
communities!

Lorin (BassNectar)
Felix the Dog (GroundScore)

Return-Path: <sfraves-return-108466-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 48130 invoked by uid 1103); 26 Nov 2003 18:03:36 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 48116 invoked from network); 26 Nov 2003 18:03:36 -0000
From: JonnyR@aol.com
Message-ID: <77.1d4cd0e6.2cf644eb@aol.com>
Date: Wed, 26 Nov 2003 13:03:23 EST
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="-----------------------------1069869803"
X-Mailer: 9.0 for Windows sub 5002
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Raver computer mods ... colored lights are not just for turntables   :)

-------------------------------1069869803
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Sound and colored lights really seem to go together. I don't have a 1200 to 
modify with colored LEDs, but I have a computer with four colors of LEDs and 
built-in blacklights. The entire case is blacklight-sensitive green plastic, and 
it glows from the lights inside as well as from external blacklights in my 
room. 

It has two types of blacklight-sensitive cables. One has the same purplish 
glow as the little collars around water bottles -- have you noticed how bright 
those are under UV light? The other cables glow greenish-white under blacklight 
and continue to glow when the blacklights are turned off. 

It's a raver computer because, in addition to the lights, it's: owned by a 
raver, built by (another) raver, and it's used to process digital photos of 
raves. It even serves to light up my room with blacklight when I want a certain 
mood. I use it for listening to music and watching DVDs (just got the DVD of 
Happy 2B Hardcore -- very fun visuals). 

Modifying and customizing things is fun. By using a few components from my 
old computer, and buying new parts on sale at Fry's, I got quite a powerful 
computer at an excellent price -- less than half the price of a new system. Best 
of all, it's unique!  

If anybody wants to see a picture, let me know, and also if you'd like to 
contact Alex, who put my computer together, because he's very good at building, 
modifying, and fixing computers.
Have a Happy Thanksgiving, everyone!
JonnyR  in Berkeley

-------------------------------1069869803--

The Canvas Gallery

Japanese & Botanical Gardens

"Subduction" this Saturday! Co-produced by Faultline

at the beautiful Canvas Gallery and will feature DJs
spinning rare Drum 'n Bass, Broken Beat and Downtempo.

rising D&B producer/DJ from England who will be
joining us on the decks.

"Nestled in the hub of the Inner-Sunset, the Canvas
has been re-launched as one of the most progressive
and diversified spaces for art, culture and
entertainment on the West Coast. We use the walls of
our dramatically redesigned interior to introduce San
Francisco to both well established and up-and-coming
artists. We also offer an ever-evolving menu of
seasonal dishes and temptations, along with an equally
tempting selection of wine, beer, sake, and espresso
drinks."  (http://www.thecanvasgallery.com)

Artist/DJ types encouraged to apply :)

8x10 Room (Average apt size)
South east san jose near the fairgrounds.. Close to all major freeways
amenities (sp?)  Washer/Dryer in the condo, Dishwasher,Wireless DSL,Cable, 
Med size but quiet complex.
Me as your roomate :)  ok well maybe that is not an amenitie but ya know...


Rent is: $500 plus utilites which will run about $100 So  6 out the door and 
your good.


If interested hit me back privately and we talk more..

PS: Available as early as Dec but Jan prefered.

 "Judge Jules is among the UK's most well-known DJ personalities. His weekly show on BBC Radio One is heard by millions. Tickets
Tickets are on sale now! You can buy tickets at all Ticketmaster outlets or at Ticketmaster.com. Tickets are also available online at newyearsevela.com, groovetickets.com and wanttickets.com. Check newyearsevela.com for a full list of authorized presale outlets.

General Admission starts at limited $30 tickets, then $35, then $40 and finally $45.

Ultra VIP Lounge
Ultra VIP passes are your ticket to taking NYE to the next level. Passes are available for $75 and include separate entrance with no wait, get the best view in the house with backstage passes, numerous free drinks, exclusive VIP area, and a free memorabilia package. VIP can be purchased from Ticketmaster or Groovetickets.


Stay Connected 
Visit us online:
www.newyearsevela.com
www.goventures.com
www.bassrush.com 

24 hr. infolines
323.960.5155 / 714.647.7777 / 702.260.8353
619.819.0211 / 415.267.6119 

 Venue Information 
Together as One '04 is located at the
LOS ANGELES SPORTS ARENA
3939 S. Figueora, Downtown LA - Festival Hours are 7pm-4am. Early arrival suggested, previous events have sold out!

For your maximum enjoyment throughout the festivities the following are provided: clean restrooms, friendly staff, plenty of food and drink concessions, full bar W/ ID, smoking areas, vendor village, and four fully themed areas for your musical and visual exploration. Capacity for this event is 20,000!

We are going to keep things short for this week, knowing

a special guest roll out from San Diego - Pete will be dropping
some downtempo w/ Kelau. On saturday we will continue to keep
things festive with us (  Kiyoshi 1 & Sunshine ) spannig various muscial
genres.

looking for a place to relax your belly's, come out to the garden!

Surreal Entertainment and SFBang! productions proudly present!=20

Winter!=20
January 31st 2004!!!=20
A mini massive to start the year off with a BANG!! and what better way =
than the joining of 2 crews to mix their magic and make your wildest =
dreams come true. Surreal Entertainment (Known for their yearly =
Earthdance,Liquid lotus festival,Refliections and their Club Further) =
branching out all the way from Arizona to join forces with SF's newest =
and quickly growing production company SFBang!, they brought=20
you GhettoTechnoSuperCaliExtraBootyLicious and if you attended that you =
know the vibe and you know the rukus and a rocking time to look forward =
to!=20

WINTER is going to be SF's First EVER snow party!=20
dance the night away in the falling snowflakes with 2 brand new =
artificial snow machines! You all are encouraged to wear stylish winter =
themed costumes. The Surreal girls will be there in full effect dressed =
as sexy snow bunnies and snow angels!!! Feel free to join them on the =
fun!=20

This party will have somthing for everyone including House, Trance, =
Breaks, Drum and Bass, and some good old fashioned HARDCORE!=20


Entertainers for the evening:=20

AK1200 (Planet of the Drums) Orlando FL -DnB,Jungle-=20
Considered to be amongst the top 10 elite in the jungle drum and bass =
arena AK1200 is nothing but legendary. Touring across the world in the =
infamous Planet of the Drums Tour with Dieselboy, AK1200 has risen to =
the top of the game. Hailing from the town where breaks were born he =
took the sound and melted it into something all on his own.=20
Jon Bishop (ICU, Tidy Trax) San Diego -HardHouse,Nrg- An all time =
favortie Jon Bishop one of the main reasons why Uk Hardhouse and NRG are =
what they are in the scene today, With his Releases on Tidy Tracks and =
his awesome live preformances this is sure to be a set that your wont =
soon forget.=20
Nicholas Bennison (AM recordings,Insomniac,Surreal Entertainment) Los =
Angeles -Tribal,Hard Trance- No stranger to the Trance scene, Bennison =
has been amazing dancers around the globe for years. With his very =
popular Cd's Trance Global Nation 2 and Crystal Vol. 2 spreading the =
word Nicholas Bennison is sure to please.=20
